definitions: extremely small in size, amount, or importance; insignificant
made from, containing, or relating to the edible seed of the peanut plant
examples: She received only peanut wages for her hard work
The company made peanut profits compared to last year
He spread peanut butter on his morning toast
The peanut oil gave the dish a nutty flavor

definitions: having the lustrous, pale color or smooth appearance characteristic of pearls
displaying white, shiny teeth that resemble pearls in their appearance
examples: The pearly morning mist covered the quiet lake
She wore a pearly white dress to the wedding
His pearly smile brightened the entire room
The dentist complimented her pearly white teeth

definitions: containing or consisting of partially decomposed vegetable matter found in bogs
having the distinctive earthy, smoky flavor characteristic of peat, especially in whisky
examples: The peaty soil was perfect for growing certain plants
They walked across the peaty moorland
He enjoyed the peaty taste of Islay scotch whisky
The peaty aroma filled the tasting room

definitions: relating to or located in the chest or breast area of the body
examples: The doctor examined his pectoral muscles after the injury
She wore a pectoral cross as part of her religious attire
The pectoral fins help the fish maintain balance
He developed strong pectoral definition through exercise

definitions: strange, odd, or unusual in a way that attracts attention or curiosity
belonging exclusively or especially to a particular person, place, or thing
examples: She noticed a peculiar smell coming from the basement
His peculiar behavior worried his friends
This species has peculiar characteristics found nowhere else
The disease shows symptoms peculiar to tropical regions

definitions: relating to or consisting of money; involving financial matters or monetary considerations
examples: The court awarded pecuniary damages to the plaintiff
He had no pecuniary interest in the company's success
Their pecuniary difficulties forced them to sell the house
The pecuniary benefits of the job were substantial

definitions: relating to teaching methods, education, or the profession of teaching
examples: Her pedagogic approach emphasized hands-on learning experiences
The conference focused on new pedagogic strategies
His pedagogic skills made complex topics easy to understand
The pedagogic materials were carefully designed for young learners

definitions: relating to the methods and practice of teaching, especially as an academic subject
examples: The pedagogical approach emphasized student-centered learning
She published several papers on pedagogical innovation
His pedagogical methods revolutionized language teaching
The pedagogical implications of technology were discussed

definitions: relating to or involving the foot or feet in anatomy
designed to be operated or controlled by pressing with the foot
examples: The pedal extremities showed signs of poor circulation
Pedal reflexes were tested during the examination
She pressed the pedal controls to operate the machine
The pedal mechanism needed regular maintenance

definitions: excessively concerned with minor details or rules; overly scholarly in a showy way
examples: His pedantic corrections of grammar annoyed everyone
The professor's pedantic lecture put students to sleep
She found his pedantic attention to footnotes exhausting
Their pedantic insistence on protocol slowed progress

definitions: relating to or designed for people who are walking rather than traveling by vehicle
lacking imagination, excitement, or originality; dull and ordinary
examples: The pedestrian crossing was clearly marked with white stripes
Pedestrian traffic increased during the lunch hour
The movie received pedestrian reviews from critics
His pedestrian writing style failed to engage readers

definitions: relating to the branch of medicine dealing with children and their diseases
examples: The pediatric ward was decorated with colorful murals
She specialized in pediatric cardiology
The pediatric dose is much smaller than the adult dose
Pediatric patients require special care and attention

definitions: having a distinguished or impressive ancestry, background, or history
bred from a line of ancestors of known quality, especially referring to animals
examples: She came from a pedigree family of lawyers and judges
The university has a pedigree reputation in science
They bought a pedigree puppy from a registered breeder
The pedigree cattle won prizes at the show

definitions: having had the outer skin or layer removed from something
wide open and watching carefully, especially used with eyes
examples: She served peeled tomatoes in the salad
The peeled paint revealed the wood underneath
Keep your eyes peeled for any suspicious activity
Everyone had their eyes peeled for the celebrity

definitions: having no equal; unmatched in excellence or quality; incomparable
examples: Her peerless beauty captivated everyone at the ball
The artist's peerless technique amazed critics
He showed peerless courage in facing the danger
The peerless quality of their products justified the price

definitions: expressing contempt or disapproval; having a disparaging or belittling effect or meaning
examples: The term became pejorative over time and is now considered offensive
His pejorative remarks about her work were uncalled for
She objected to the pejorative tone of the article
The pejorative connotations of the word made it unsuitable

definitions: relating to or located in the pelvis, the bony structure in the lower trunk
examples: The doctor ordered a pelvic examination for the patient
Pelvic floor exercises can help with incontinence
She experienced pelvic pain during her pregnancy
The pelvic bones showed signs of an old fracture

definitions: relating to or prescribing the punishment of offenders under the legal system
examples: The penal code was revised to include cyber crimes
She studied penal reform in graduate school
The penal system faced criticism for overcrowding
Penal sanctions were imposed for violations

definitions: drawn, written, or marked with a pencil rather than ink
tentatively planned or scheduled, subject to change or confirmation
examples: The penciled sketch showed the artist's initial concept
Her penciled notes filled the margins
We have you penciled in for Tuesday afternoon
The meeting is only penciled on the calendar

definitions: drawn, written, or marked with a pencil rather than permanent ink
tentatively planned or scheduled, subject to change or confirmation
examples: The pencilled corrections were barely visible on the manuscript
She made pencilled annotations in the book
You're pencilled in for Thursday but please confirm
The event was only pencilled on the schedule

definitions: hanging down loosely; suspended from above
remaining undecided or incomplete; awaiting settlement or completion
examples: The pendant branches of the willow tree swayed gently
Pendant lights illuminated the dining room
Several pendant matters required the board's attention
The pendant lawsuit continued for months

definitions: awaiting decision or settlement; not yet decided or resolved
about to happen or likely to happen soon; imminent
examples: The pending lawsuit kept them from selling the property
Several applications are still pending approval
With the storm pending, they cancelled outdoor events
The pending changes will affect all employees

definitions: hanging down loosely or swinging freely; suspended so as to swing
examples: The pendulous branches created a natural canopy
Her pendulous earrings swayed as she walked
The dog's pendulous jowls gave him a sad expression
Pendulous breasts can cause back pain

definitions: able to pierce through or enter into something; sharp and forceful
showing keen insight or understanding; perceptive and intellectually sharp
examples: The penetrating cold made everyone shiver
A penetrating scream echoed through the night
Her penetrating analysis revealed hidden problems
He fixed her with a penetrating gaze

definitions: having the ability or tendency to penetrate or pierce through something
examples: The penetrative power of X-rays allows medical imaging
This oil has excellent penetrative properties
His penetrative intellect solved complex problems easily
The penetrative force of the drill was impressive

definitions: relating to or affecting the penis, the male reproductive organ
examples: The patient underwent penile surgery to correct the condition
Penile cancer is relatively rare in developed countries
The doctor discussed penile health with his patient
Penile implants can treat severe erectile dysfunction

definitions: relating to, located on, or characteristic of a peninsula
examples: The peninsular region enjoys a mild maritime climate
Peninsular Spain refers to the mainland territory
They studied the peninsular wildlife of Florida
The peninsular location provided strategic advantages

definitions: feeling or showing sorrow and regret for having done wrong; repentant
examples: The penitent thief asked for forgiveness
She adopted a penitent tone when apologizing
His penitent letter moved her to tears
The penitent expression on his face seemed genuine

definitions: relating to or expressing penance, repentance, or religious discipline for sin
examples: The penitential prayers were recited during Lent
She maintained a penitential attitude throughout the service
The penitential rite began the religious ceremony
Medieval penitential practices included fasting and prayer

definitions: relating to or used for imprisonment, especially in a federal or state prison
examples: The penitentiary system underwent major reforms
He served time in a federal penitentiary facility
Penitentiary sentences are given for serious crimes
The penitentiary guards maintained strict security

definitions: having no money at all; extremely poor or destitute
examples: The penniless artist lived in a tiny studio apartment
After the business failed, he was left penniless
She arrived penniless but determined to succeed
The penniless immigrants sought work desperately

definitions: engaged in deep or serious thought, often with a touch of sadness
examples: She sat in pensive silence watching the sunset
His pensive mood worried his friends
The portrait captured her pensive expression perfectly
He became pensive when discussing his childhood

definitions: confined, shut up, or kept in; especially referring to repressed emotions
examples: His pent frustration finally exploded in anger
The pent energy needed a positive outlet
Pent emotions can cause psychological problems
The pent demand was released when stores reopened

definitions: having five angles and five sides; shaped like a pentagon
examples: The pentagonal building housed the defense department
She drew a perfect pentagonal shape
The pentagonal tiles created an interesting pattern
Each pentagonal face of the structure was identical

definitions: consisting of or using a musical scale of five notes per octave
examples: The pentatonic scale is common in Asian music
She composed a beautiful pentatonic melody
Many folk songs use pentatonic patterns
The pentatonic harmony created a distinctive sound

definitions: relating to Pentecost or to Christian groups emphasizing direct personal experience of God
examples: The pentecostal church emphasized speaking in tongues
She attended a pentecostal revival meeting
Pentecostal worship includes enthusiastic singing and prayer
The pentecostal movement spread rapidly worldwide

definitions: occurring immediately before the last one in a series; second to last
examples: The penultimate chapter revealed the killer's identity
She finished in the penultimate position
This is the penultimate step in the process
The penultimate episode set up the finale perfectly

definitions: inhabited or populated by people; having residents or inhabitants
examples: The newly peopled territories needed infrastructure
A densely peopled neighborhood surrounded the park
The sparsely peopled region had few services
These islands were peopled centuries ago

definitions: full of energy and high spirits; lively and enthusiastic
examples: The peppy cheerleader motivated the crowd
She gave a peppy presentation that engaged everyone
His peppy personality made him popular at parties
The peppy music got everyone dancing

definitions: relating to digestion or the digestive system, especially the stomach
examples: The patient was diagnosed with a peptic ulcer
Peptic enzymes help break down proteins
She took medication for peptic disorders
The peptic activity increased after meals

definitions: recognized, understood, or interpreted through the senses or mind
regarded as being something, whether accurately or not; believed to exist
examples: The perceived threat made everyone nervous
Her perceived weakness was actually her strength
The perceived value exceeded the actual cost
There's a perceived need for better security

definitions: able to be seen, heard, or noticed; detectable by the senses or mind
examples: There was a barely perceptible change in temperature
The perceptible tremor in her voice revealed nervousness
A perceptible improvement occurred after the treatment
The difference was perceptible to trained observers

definitions: having or showing sensitive insight and understanding; quick to notice and understand
examples: Her perceptive comments impressed the interview panel
The perceptive teacher noticed the student's distress
He made perceptive observations about human nature
The perceptive analysis revealed hidden patterns

definitions: relating to the ability to interpret or become aware of something through the senses
examples: The perceptual skills of artists are highly developed
Children's perceptual abilities develop gradually
The study examined perceptual differences between groups
Perceptual disorders can affect learning

definitions: relating to or produced by striking or percussion; having a sharp, striking quality
examples: The percussive rhythm drove the dance music
She enjoyed the percussive sounds of the drums
His percussive piano style was instantly recognizable
The percussive effects added drama to the performance

definitions: traveling from place to place; wandering or migrating, especially over long distances
coming from another country or place; foreign or exotic in origin
examples: The peregrine falcon is known for its incredible speed
Peregrine species migrate thousands of miles
His peregrine adventures took him across continents
The peregrine plants adapted to local conditions

definitions: leaving no opportunity for denial or refusal; imperative and absolute
insisting on immediate attention or obedience in an arrogantly domineering way
examples: The judge issued a peremptory order to appear
His peremptory dismissal shocked everyone
She spoke in a peremptory tone that brooked no argument
His peremptory manner alienated his colleagues

definitions: lasting or existing for a long or apparently infinite time; enduring
recurring again and again; happening repeatedly or all the time
examples: These perennial plants bloom every spring
She grew perennial herbs in her garden
Budget concerns are a perennial problem for schools
He's the perennial favorite at the tournament

definitions: having all the required or desirable elements, qualities, or characteristics; as good as possible
complete and absolute; total and unqualified in extent or degree
precisely accurate or exact; exactly suitable for a particular purpose
examples: She achieved a perfect score on the test
The weather was perfect for our picnic
It was a perfect disaster from start to finish
He maintained perfect silence during the ceremony
This is the perfect solution to our problem
You arrived at the perfect moment

definitions: brought to completion or perfection; refined to the highest degree possible
examples: The perfected technique took years to develop
Her perfected recipe won the competition
The perfected design eliminated all previous flaws
His perfected skills made the task look easy
